title: Sony Mastering Requirement PS3: R002 - Package file is created with the latest version of the Publishing Tools
custom_preconds: The master package is created under the correct procedure using the latest version of System File Utility for PlayStation®3 and the make_package_npdrm command in the PlayStation®3 Library SDK.
custom_steps:
1) Using the “make_package_npdrm.exe” Command Line tool on a command prompt screen of a PC, run the command “make_package_npdrm.exe -c” on the HG/DGP/HGP/AC.

Make Package tool commands for Package check, folder and files list, and extraction
As an administrator open a command prompt and change the directory to where the make_package_npdrm.exe is located (e.g. from current Dell laptop location C:\usr\local\cell\host-win32\bin)

Check: Type the following without quotes "make_package_npdrm.exe -c <build location\PACKAGE> >check.txt"

(Crabtree, please explain why this step is even needed)


2) Using the “make_package_npdrm.exe” Command Line tool on a command prompt screen of a PC, run the command “make_package_npdrm.exe -x” on the HG/DGP/HGP/AC to expand it and obtain the EBOOT.BIN file.

Assuming your Command Prompt is still pointed to the tools area, run the Extract command

Extract: Type the following without quotes "make_package_npdrm.exe -x <build location\PACKAGE>

This will "expand" the package to the current tools location. It will appear as a folder labeled with the apps Service ID. Inside this folder is a folder labeled USRDIR which holds the EBOOT.BIN file.

3) Using the latest Disc Image Generator for PlayStation®3 Command Line tool (ps3cmd.exe) on a command prompt screen of a PC, run the command “ps3cmd.exe veri_file --sdk_ver xxx” on the EBOOT.BIN file. (NOTE: for “xxx” following “sdk_ver“, enter the SDK version which has been used for master creation.)

Point to the As an administrator open a command prompt and change the directory to where the PS3cmd.exe is located (e.g. from current Dell laptop location Loacl Disk (C:)  C:\Ps3Tools\ps3gen\tool)
To verify EBOOT.BIN: Type the following without quotes "ps3cmd.exe veri_file --sdk_ver ### <extract build\EBOOT.BIN> >verifile.txt
Replace ### with the SDK version used to create the package as noted in the Check file from step 1 (e.g. 475 - formatting must not include the "point" or any characters after the first 3)

OR (some say checking the below is not good enough...we'll need to confirm)

Open the pkg_verify.log file in Console to confirm the Expected results.
custom_expected:
− Packaging errors are not reported in the HG/DGP/HGP/AC information displayed by the “make_package_npdrm.exe -c” command.
− If the DGP/HGP contains an EBOOT.BIN file, the EBOOT.BIN file is located in the USRDIR directory (the “make_package_npdrm.exe -x” command will expand the DGP/HGP).
− Errors are not reported in the ps3cmd.exe output. (The “ps3cmd.exe ver_file –-sdk_ver xxx” command will perform a series of checks and report the test results on-screen.)

title: Sony Mastering Requirement PS3: R014 - EBOOT.BIN is included for cumulative patch packages.
custom_preconds:
Explanation:
The first patch package for incremental patches is also a cumulative patch package and must include
EBOOT.BIN. Upon creating an incremental patch package, if there is no change in EBOOT.BIN and no
executable (sprx/self file) is included, the incremental patch package does not have to include
EBOOT.BIN.

Explanation:
If the package filename is changed after it is created, this can hinder the correct execution of access rights management and application patching.
Check method:
Any changes in the filename can be detected by using the check feature of the make_package_npdrm command. Compare the filename with the content ID.
QA Note
− After the DGP/HGP file has been uploaded to the TPPS, the application version and package version parameters will be appended to the file name. This is not a violation of this TRC and should be ignored.
− When performing the following test, use the latest version of the “make_package_npdrm.exe” Command Line tool.

NOTE: This is all done with scripts so unlikely to ever be an issue.
custom_steps:
1) Using the latest “make_package_npdrm.exe” Command Line tool on a command prompt screen of a PC, run the command “make_package_npdrm.exe -c” on the DGP/HGP.

Example:
Type the following without quotes "make_package_npdrm.exe -c <build location\PACKAGE>

2) Within the command window, there will be a list of the files within the DGP/HGP
custom_expected: The file type EBOOT.BIN exists for cumulative DGP/HGP with executable files

title: Sony Platform Requirement: R056 - The title supports render resolution 480 (4:3) if it targets NTSC regions, and render resolution 576 (4:3) if it targets PAL regions.
custom_preconds:
− Wide-screen (squeezed) televisions 480 (16:9) and 576 (16:9) can also be supported.
− Both NTSC and PAL can be supported. However, PlayStation®3 consoles other than those targeting PAL regions do not support PAL output.

− In the Video Output Settings set the output to HDMI, Component/D-Terminal, Composite/S Video, or AV MULTI/SCART to perform these checks.
− For render resolution 480 and 576, please refer to Appendix “Supplementary notes for requirements” at the end of this document.
custom_steps:
1) Select “Display Settings” under the “Settings” column on the XMB™ menu.
2) Select “Video Output Settings."
3) Select the output to either of "HDMI,” “Component/D-Terminal,” “Composite/S Video,” or”AV MULTI/SCART.”
4) Set the resolution to 480 or 576.
5) Set the Screen ratio to 4:3.
6) Select the application under the "Game" column on the XMB™ menu.
7) Check throughout the application.
custom_expected:
The application supports render resolution 480 (4:3) if it targets NTSC regions, and render resolution 576 (4:3) if it targets PAL regions.
Notes
According to the terminal selected in Procedure 3, how to set in Procedure 4 differs.
− When "HDMI" is selected, untick items other than "HDMI" > "Custom" > "480p or 576p."
− When "Component/D-Terminal" is selected, untick items other than "Component/D-Terminal" > "480p or 576p."
− When "Composite/S Video" is selected, there is no setting in the Procedure 4.
− Select "AV MULTI/SCART" > "RGB" > "R480p or 576p."

title: Sony Platform Requirement: R057 - The title does not require change of the video output mode that the title was booted in.
custom_preconds:
Although the title can change the video output mode, it is possible for the user's television not to support the new output mode. Therefore the title must be able to run without changing modes.
For details, refer to the document "Application Requirements (Graphics)".
QA Note
− It is not prohibited that the application supports change in video modes. However, it is recommended that the user is able to play in the video output mode which was set at boot without being required to change the video output mode.
− In the Video Output Settings set the output to HDMI, Component/D-Terminal, Composite/S Video, or AV MULTI/SCART to perform these checks.
custom_steps:
1) Select the application under the “Game” column on the XMB™ menu.
2) Check throughout the application.
custom_expected: The application does not require changing video resolution at boot.

title: Sony Platform Requirement: R058 - If the video output mode is changed after boot only the available video output modes as determined by the System Software are used
custom_preconds:
Explanation:
Before changing the video output mode, check that the target video output mode is supported. This check must be made every time an application is booted, as the user may switch TVs. Titles that support stereoscopic 3D using HDMI/SimulView™ always change the video output mode after boot; in this case also, a check must first be made to ensure that 3D stereo/SimulView™ output is possible, and output stereoscopic 3D/SimulView™ image only if it is possible.
For details, refer to the documents "Video Configuration Utility Overview", "Application Requirements (Graphics)", and "3D Stereo/SimulView™ Programming Guide".
QA Note
For R058a, set the Video Output Settings set the output to HDMI, Component/D-Terminal, Composite/S Video, or AV MULTI/SCART to perform these checks.
custom_steps:
1) Select the application under the “Game” column on the XMB™ menu.
2) Proceed to where the application changes the video output.
custom_expected:
Only the video output determined by the System Software is used.

title: Sony Quality Requirements PS3: Operation test R019 - Display is correct in all supported video output modes. Sound output is correct for all supported audio formats.
custom_preconds:
− Video Note:
− Component, D5 terminal, and HDMI cables can display 1080p resolution for games.
− For HDMI, manual and automatic video output settings can be configured.
− It is acceptable that the application implements the specification to adjust the resolution to 1080i when the application supporting 480/720p runs on a HDTV which does not support 720p. For more details, please refer to the “Application Requirements (Graphics)”
− Audio Note:
− For AV MULTI OUT, there are no options to manually configure audio output settings for this connector type.
− For HDMI, there are manual and automatic output settings to be configured for this connector type.
− For Digital out (Optical), there is only manual audio output settings to be configured for this connector type.
− Factory default of audio output settings supports every connector.
− Ensure that the result outputted by Check for 「RESOLUTION」「SOUND_FORMAT」match as marked at "Render resolutions supported at boot “and” Audio formats supported at boot" of the Master Specifications Form.
− For video output, please refer to Appendix “Supplementary notes for requirements” at the end of "ps3testcases_forTRC4.51_English.pdf"

title: Sony Quality Requirements PS3: Operation test R020 - When the PS button is pressed while the title is running, the system menu appears and is correctly operable
custom_preconds:
Explanation:
− Check the behavior during loads, movie playback, and while saving save data.
− The system menu is layered over a dimmed application screen when the PS button is pressed. The system menu is displayed by the System Software. For the menu to be displayed correctly and become immediately operable, it is necessary for the application to execute flips correctly. It is also necessary to take into account the processing load required for the system menu. (It is acceptable to avoid rendering and sound generation altogether by pausing the application while the system menu is being displayed.)
− For game termination to be executed correctly, the application must carry out appropriate termination processing. If the application's termination processing does not complete under a certain time (approximately 10 seconds) the system will force it to exit and emit warning beeps. Check to make sure that the application does not undergo forced termination.
custom_steps:
1) Select the application under the "Game" column on the XMB™.
2) Press the PS button for a short time.
custom_expected:
− The XMB™ menu appears immediately after the PS button is pressed.
− All menu items are immediately operable and function.
Notes
In Procedure 2, also ensure that the Impose screen is displayed by pressing the PS button for approximately 2 seconds.

title: Sony Quality Requirements PS3: Operation test R025 - The title runs correctly when the patch/additional content is applied.
custom_preconds:
Check method:
Check that the title runs correctly with the patch/additional content in all possible combinations and orders with previous releases (disc boot games, HDD boot games, patches, and additional contents).

QA Note
− Cumulative patches are those that include all the contents of patches delivered in the past.
− Incremental patches are those that do not include the patches delivered in the past but only the latest contents.
− Test cases R025a, R025b, R025e, and R025h apply to both cumulative and incremental patches.
− Test cases R025c and R025f only apply to cumulative patches.
− Test cases R025d and R025g only apply to incremental patches.

title: Sony Programs and Content Information PS3: R027 - Content information and program files are created correctly in the appropriate formats and checked with the check feature of the System Software.
custom_preconds:
Check method:
The check feature can be invoked by pressing the △ button with the game icon in focus and selecting "Check". Use this feature to check the content information and program file formats, and make sure that no errors are reported. For the types of possible errors, refer to the document "System Software Overview".
If the title also supports save data or game data, use this feature and check content information. For save data that does not affect trophy obtainment, it is not a problem if the "Protected file not found." error is reported.

QA Note
− The “Check” option is only present on Debugging Station to check mainly specification errors. (There is a case that errors other than specifications are reported. If any error is detected, the current specification of the item is displayed.
− Note that a “WARNING” displayed in STATUS may not necessarily be a failure issue. For questions, contact SCE via the PlayStation®3 Developer Network website (https://ps3.scedev.net/).

2) Highlight the application under the “Game” column on the XMB™ menu.

title: Sony Text and Graphics PS3: R030 - Essential display items can always be displayed
custom_preconds:
"Essential display items" refer to texts and graphics that must be displayed according to the TRC, error messages and warning messages, legal texts such as the EULA and other copyright indications, PlayStation®Network Online IDs (to distinguish between users on the network), operation instructions and game rule explanations, and other text and graphics required to appropriately advance gameplay. Note the following when designing and implementing the application.
Because the displayable area depends on each television, it is possible for items rendered to be cut off if placed too close to the screen edges.
− Either design the application screen so that essential display items remain within the displayable area of the television (approximately 85% by 85% of the height and width) or provide an adjustment feature so that the user can always display the entire screen.
−When displaying a long character string, either prepare a display area large enough for the maximum length or enable scrolling. It is also possible to provide a link to a separate dialog that will show all the information.
custom_steps:
1) Select the application under the “Game” column on the XMB™ menu.
2) Check throughout the application.
custom_expected:
All essential display items are always displayed complying to one of the following.
− It is designed so that they remain within the displayable area of the television (85% by 85% of the height and width).
− An adjustment feature is provided so that the user can always display the entire screen
− Scrolling is enabled.
− A link to a separate dialog is provided that will show all the information.

title: Sony Network PS3: R036 - If network functionalities are used: The title displays appropriate messages when network errors occur.
custom_preconds:
Note:
− When the system detects a network error and displays a message, it is not necessary for the application to display an error message. For more information, refer to the document "Application Requirements (Network)".
− An appropriate message can be displayed by passing a supported error number to the message dialog utility. Refer to the document "Message Dialog Utility Overview" for details.
− If a network error message cannot be displayed immediately because of a dialog, an on-screen keyboard, or a network utility, it may either be displayed at the next opportunity or omitted altogether. (Normal messaging regarding network connection must then be resumed.)
− When the application displays a message, it is recommended that the cause of the network error is included in the message as much as possible so the user can determine how to resolve the error, if the cause can be determined by the application from the condition or status before/after the error.
− Regarding appropriate handling of when there is no response from the server or a game opponent for a long time, refer to the explanation of R180.
custom_steps:
1) Select the application under the "Game" column on the XMB™ menu.
2) Proceed to where the application is connected to the network.
3) Disconnect the PlayStation®3 system from the network.
custom_expected:
A message according to the situation is displayed.
Notes
− As for network disconnection, implement the following methods, etc.
− In a wireless LAN environment, unplug the LAN cable of the access point.
− In a wired environment, unplug the LAN cable connected to WAN of the router.
− When a communication error occurs in connecting to the network, also ensure a message according to the situation is displayed.

title: Sony Network PS3: R038 - If a sign-out from PlayStation®Network occurs, the title makes an appropriate notification to the user and then allows the user to use a feature within the application to sign in again at the appropriate timing.
custom_preconds:
− When a sign-out occurs, immediately display a message that includes the following information.
− The fact that a sign-out has occurred
− Features that have become unusable and other inconveniences for the user due to the sign-out
− The timing at which the title allows the user to sign in again must be when there is no negative impact on the user. A sign-in can be postponed until the user next attempts to use a feature that requires a sign-in.
− To sign in again, the title must obtain a user confirmation and then call the network start dialog utility. It is not acceptable to enable a sign-in only from the System Software menu, or execute an infinite retry to attempt a sign-in.
custom_steps:
1) Select "User" who can use network features and sign in to the PSNSM.
2) Select the application under the "Game" column on the XMB™ menu.
3) Proceed to where the application is connected to the network.
4) Press the PS button for a short time to display the XMB™menu when connected to the network.
5) Highlight "Account Management" under the “PSN” column.
6) Press the △button then select "Sign Out. "
7) Proceed to where it is required to sign in to the PSNSM again
custom_expected:
− A message including the following information is displayed:
− That sign-out occurred
− Which features have become unusable and other inconveniences for the user due to sign-out
− The application calls the network start dialog utility and provides an opportunity to sign in again when the user accesses a feature that requires a sign-in.
Notes
In Procedure 1, if there is no user who can use network features, create a new "User."

title: Sony Network PS3: R182 - If network functionalities are used, the title allows accesses only to websites/local files predetermined by the title.
custom_preconds:
− Unless there is a specific need to do so, do not implement a feature where the user can specify an arbitrary website and access it (when using the web browser utility, do not enable the history, bookmark, set-homepage/jump-to-homepage, and URL input functions). Moreover, within the title-specified website/local file (including top page and all linked pages), do not implement a feature by which the user can specify and access an arbitrary website, or do not provide a link to a page with such a feature.
− Calling a full browser using a web browser utility API will enable the user to access an arbitrary website, however, do not implement such a feature unless there is a specific reason to do so. When implementing such a feature, calling a full browser will cause the application to terminate, proper operation must be ensured upon its reboot after the full browser is closed.
− Implementing a feature that does not match this requirement, in other words, enabling the user to access arbitrary websites without using a full browser will incur an extensive increase in memory usage and necessitate the implementation of proper parental controls. If it is necessary to allow such accesses, contact SCE via the PlayStation®3 Developer Network website (https://ps3.scedev.net/).
custom_steps:
1) Select the application under the “Game” column on the XMB™ menu.
2) Proceed to where the application allows user to access a website/local files.
custom_expected:
− The application must only allow access to pre-approved websites/local files.
− The application does not implement a feature within the title-specified website/local file by which the user can specify and access an arbitrary website.
Notes
The following options (which is activated via the △ button) should be disabled:
− Search
− Bookmarks
− Address Entry under File
− History

title: Sony Platform Requirement PS3: R174 - If user accounts are managed on a non-SCE server, the user only has to sign in to PSN (with the Online ID) to access the user's account on the non-SCE server.
custom_preconds:
− Log in operation with the user's account on a non-SCE server must not be required. (Except for linking the PSNSM Online ID with the user's account on the non-SCE server at the beginning.)
− For sign-in and how to create a new user, please refer to Appendix “Supplementary notes for Procedures of testcases” at the end of this document.
custom_steps:
1) Select "User" who can use network features and ensure the user has not signed in to the PSNSM.
2) Select the application under the "Game" column on the XMB™ menu.
3) Attempt to connect to online.
custom_expected:
− The PSNSM sign-in screen appears and the user is prompted to input their Sony Entertainment Network account sign-in ID and password.
− Log in operation with the user's account on the non-SCE server is not required.
Notes
− In Procedure 2, the state that the user can select "Sign In" means he/she has not signed in. When the user can select "Account Management," highlight "Account Management," press the △ button to display the options menu, and select "Sign Out."
− In Procedure 1, when there is no user who can use network features, create a new "User."

5) Select the application under the "Game" column on the XMB™ menu.
